awd_titl_txt: Using organic biomarker paleohypsometry to reconstruct the punctuated uplift history of the Northern Tibetan Plateau
awd_abstract_narration:
The Tibetan Plateau has long served as a natural laboratory for the study of extreme topography related to continent-continent collisions. The northern Tibetan Plateau is a key location for understanding how the India-Asia collision produced high topography in the continental interior 1,000 km away from the tectonic plate boundary. This project will reconstruct the history of past topographies of the northern Tibetan Plateau by using a newly developed quantitative approach. Data generated from this project will reveal when and how the northern Tibetan Plateau was uplifted to the present elevation and will help to differentiate between tectonic models. Broader impacts of this project include: 1. support of two early-career investigators, 2. training of graduate and undergraduate students in field and laboratory analyses, 3. enhancement of national and international collaborations between institutions in the United States and Canada, 4. incorporation of analytical techniques into undergraduate courses, and 5. community outreach events, such as mentoring underrepresented minority students with science projects, delivering presentations and field-based videos, and examining geology specimens at local charter schools.

Understanding how an orogenic plateau formed far away from a plate boundary has long been a dynamic and controversial topic in continental dynamics. High topography is the manifestation of crustal and mantle processes, and this project aims at understanding which mechanism (underthrusting, mantle dynamics, infilling of ‘piggy-back’ basins, or crustal flow) controls the construction of high topography at the north margin of the Tibetan Plateau and what implications it bears for the India-Asia collision. The project will test the hypothesis that high topography in northern Tibetan Plateau has been constructed during a pulse of outward expansion from 15 to 8 million years ago. The project investigators will first develop an integrated approach that combines techniques in sedimentary geology, organic geochemistry, and geomorphology. The investigators will test the approach with Holocene sediments from three selected river catchments within the Qilian Shan region and use organic geochemistry proxies, i.e., hydrogen isotopes of n-alkanes derived from terrestrial higher-plant leaf waxes and distribution of microbial glycerol tetraethers produced in soils, to calibrate the relationships between proxies and the elevation distributions of river catchments (hypsometry). The investigators will apply the calibrated proxies to well-dated sedimentary rocks in the foreland basin of Hexi Corridor and the intermontane Qaidam Basin to constrain the elevational history of the Qilian Shan range between the two basins. This approach will be of broad use in similar climatic regimes in orogenic belts in the western United States, the Andes, and other parts of the Tibetan Plateau.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Via the collaborative effort between the LSU and the University of Oklahoma over the course of the project, we have achieved two goals: (1) establishing a new approach in paleo-altimetry – a discipline aimed at providing a quantitative estimation of the paleo-topography of orogenic mountain ranges and (2) reconstructing a record of paleo-topography and paleo-hydrology across the northern Tibetan plateau region comprising of the intermountain Qaidam Basin and the foreland Hexi Corridor and the Qilian Shan fold-thrust mountain range.

In the following, we summarize the main results achieved by completing the project.

We have collected and analyzed modern precipitations from the NWW-SEE trending Qilian Shan Range along a climatic gradient from semi-arid with annual rainfall of about 250-400 mm in the eastern-central Qilian Shan Range to an arid region with less than 150 mm of precipitation in the western Qilian Shan Range. Our project reveals that despite the significant difference in climate, modern precipitation samples preserve the isotopic signal of elevation. Modern precipitations record a decreasing trend in the oxygen and hydrogen isotope values with increasing elevation, which is the foundation of quantitative elevation estimation with the isotopic tool. Our project also reveals that the Holocene sediments preserve the isotopic signal at the same rate as the modern meteoric precipitations, along with a strong temperature signal. The results generated from the Holocene sediments prove that the biological markers (biomarkers) derived from the standing vegetation and microbial communities in sediments are practical archives and, hence, can be used as a proxy for reconstructing the paleo-temperature and paleo-hydrology.

The project has produced results from multiple sedimentary sections in the Qaidam basin and the foreland Hexi Corridor – the bounding basins on both sides of the Qilian Shan Range. The main result via the integrated use of the biomarker-founded temperature proxy and the isotope-based precipitation proxy reveals that the northern Tibetan Plateau achieved a high topography during the middle-late Miocene with a difference in elevation between the mountain ranges and the low-land reference basins like the present. This topographic setting was regulating the late Miocene-modern climatic and vegetation evolutions.

The project results also reveal a fundamental shift in the climatic regime in the Qaidam Basin across the Eocene-Oligocene Transition (EOT) – the boundary event of the Cenozoic when the Earth’s climate transitioned from the ice-free greenhouse state to the glaciated state with polar continental ice sheets like the present. The climatic shift was accompanied by the expansion of paleo-lake in the Qaidam Basin, a change from a drying to a wetting regime, which is opposite to other discoveries across the EOT in different continents where dry climates were reported, for example, in the Western Interior in the USA.

The last main point is the gradient in climate and vegetation cover along the transect normal to the Qilian Shan Range. Close to the Qilian Shan Range, the climate was wet and covered by dense vegetation. For example, in the western transect with results from three sedimentary sections, we found that the hydro-climatic conditions became much stressed just tens of kilometers away from the mountain front, and that reflects on the isotopic composition of biomarkers preserved in sediments or sedimentary rocks. This unique topography-vegetation-climatic configuration is not isolated but rather a broad observation in other mountainous ranges in arid- and semi-arid areas. The specific configuration highlights the role of high mountain ranges in governing local hydrology, agriculture, and hydrology and hence may provide guides for policy making.

The project has also generated positive societal impact. PI has developed a systematic outreach activity series around the project by (1) enhancing graduate training, (2) strengthening the college geology curriculum, and (3) promoting Earth Science education in local schools. The project has supported four Ph.D. students on their thesis research works. The Ph.D. students have been trained in and mastered the analytical techniques in a new research field, compound-specific isotope analysis (CSIA), and biomarker analysis. The Ph.D. students have published six first-author papers in excellent discipline journals (EPSL, GSA Bulletin, etc.) and developed a MatLab code as an automation tool in biomarker studies. The Ph.D. students have disseminated their research results at the college, sectional, national, and international meetings. Samples from the project were also used in the LSU Senior Honor Option Program project. The research results generated from the project have been used in undergraduate and graduate-level courses. Three new courses benefiting from the project results are (a) Advanced Sedimentology, (b) Stable Isotopes and Global Hydrological Cycle, and (c) Stable Isotopes and Biomarkers. PI has mentored three middle school students from different schools on the science fair projects. All three students did outstanding work and were ranked high in school and regional competitions. Materials from research activities have been used to disseminate Earth Science to elementary school students.
